title: NASA Confirms That Goop Healing Stickers Are a Scam
author: Gabriella Paiella
cleaned_text: Every bit of advice or product sold by Goop ultimately boils down to an attempt to stave off death. The [vaginal jade eggs,](http://www.thecut.com/2017/01/10-alternatives-to-goops-sold-out-vaginal-jade-eggs.html) the [goats' milk cleanse,](http://goop.com/you-probably-have-a-parasite-heres-what-to-do-about-it/) even the [bees stinging you all over your face](http://www.thecut.com/2016/04/gwyneth-paltrow-bees-beauty.html) — all of it. Recently, the site's staff has been [having a "major obsession"](http://goop.com/wearable-stickers-that-promote-healing-really/) with Body Vibes stickers, which retail for $60 for a pack of ten and are claimed to "rebalance the energy frequency in our bodies." They also look like something you kept on your Trapper Keeper in elementary school. More specifically, they write that, "Body Vibes stickers (made with the same conductive carbon material NASA uses to line space suits so they can monitor an astronaut's vitals during wear) come pre-programmed to an ideal frequency, allowing them to target imbalances." This was quickly debunked [when Gizmodo contacted NASA](https://gizmodo.com/nasa-calls-bullshit-on-goops-120-bio-frequency-healing-1796309360) and were told that they "do not have any conductive carbon material lining the spacesuits." Mark Shelhamer, who used to be the chief scientist at NASA's human-research division, weighed in as well, saying, "Wow. What a load of BS this is." And ultimately, stickers or no stickers, death comes for us all.
